coredata.dc:description: The design and optimization of electrolyte/electrode interface significantly affects the performance of solid-state batteries. Here, we propose hierarchical composite solid electrolytes (H-CSEs) for synergistically stabilizing lithium anode and constructing cathode continuous ion conducting networks. Interestingly, the H-CSEs could not only build a stable multiphase solid electrolyte interface, but also regulate the internal electric field of solid battery. XPS revealed that the additives including fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), dipheny (2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl) phosphorus oxide (TPO) and SnF2 were involved in the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) rich in LiF, Li3PO4 and LixSn. While the FEC and SnF2 were participated in the formation of cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) rich in LiF and Sn. In addition, the finite element simulations confirmed that the H-CSEs could reduce local electric field, regulate ion transport flux, and promote the preferential deposition of Li+ on the anode plane. These results synergistically enhanced the reaction kinetics. As expected, the Li/H-CSEs/LiFePO4 battery showed a specific capacity of 102 mAh g−1 at 1.0C after 300 cycles. The capacity of Li/H-CSEs/S cell was 850 mAh g−1 at 0.2C after 60 cycles.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The design and optimization of electrolyte/electrode interface significantly affects the performance of solid-state batteries. Here, we propose hierarchical composite solid electrolytes (H-CSEs) for synergistically stabilizing lithium anode and constructing cathode continuous ion conducting networks. Interestingly, the H-CSEs could not only build a stable multiphase solid electrolyte interface, but also regulate the internal electric field of solid battery. XPS revealed that the additives including fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), dipheny (2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl) phosphorus oxide (TPO) and SnF2 were involved in the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) rich in LiF, Li3PO4 and LixSn. While the FEC and SnF2 were participated in the formation of cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) rich in LiF and Sn. In addition, the finite element simulations confirmed that the H-CSEs could reduce local electric field, regulate ion transport flux, and promote the preferential deposition of Li+ on the anode plane. These results synergistically enhanced the reaction kinetics. As expected, the Li/H-CSEs/LiFePO4 battery showed a specific capacity of 102 mAh g−1 at 1.0C after 300 cycles. The capacity of Li/H-CSEs/S cell was 850 mAh g−1 at 0.2C after 60 cycles.

A hierarchical composite solid electrolyte was proposed for stabilizing lithium anode and constructing cathode ion conducting network. The resulting all-solid-state battery showed an improved reaction kinetics.

ce:section.ce:para: To date, solid state batteries (SSBs) with excellent energy density and unparalleled safety have been a hot topic in battery development [1,2]. Regrettably, the limited solid-solid contact between solid electrolyte and electrode reduces the interfacial ion transfer efficiency, which greatly hinders the reaction kinetics of SSBs [3,4]. The composite solid electrolytes (CSEs), which inherit the advantages of ceramics and polymers and combine interfacial continuity, structural and compositional tunability, are the key components of solid-state batteries and have attracted widespread research attention for developing high-performance SSBs [5,6]. Specially, the interfacial chemistry of CSE affects the Li-ion transport dynamics [7,8]. Kang and co-authors constructed the BaTiO3-Li0.33La0.56TiO3-x-poly(vinylidene difluoride) CSEs, and the Li+ transport was greatly facilitated by the internal multi-scale effect, strong Lewis acid-base interaction and piezoelectric effect of BaTiO3 [9]. Despite the fruitful results of these CSEs, the ionic conduction in the electrolyte, at the electrolyte/electrode interface, and within the cathode are still obstacles to the development of SSBs. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop a CSE that with good compatibility for both anode and cathode [10,11]. To overcome the aforementioned shortcomings, current research efforts are devoted to constructing an elastic interface layer to enhance the contact area between the solid electrolyte and the electrode [12,13]. For example, constructing an artificial SEI with high interface energy and high ion conductivity at the anode interface improves the nucleation energy and inhibits the penetration of lithium dendrites [14,15]. Although these strategies have shown significant effectiveness on the anode. However, the construction of an elastic interface has little effect on the ion conduction at the cathode [16,17].

To improve the interface compatibility and ion transport kinetics on the cathode side of solid-state batteries, more attention needs to be paid to the surface and interface characteristics of the cathode. The following strategies are shown potential: (i) Integrating the solid electrolytes onto cathode, however, this strategy sacrifices the energy density of the battery [18,19]. (ii) Adding a small amount of electrolyte or ionic liquid to improve the interface contact and ion conduction inside the cathode, but its energy density and safety still need to be discussed [20–22]. Besides, the instability between solid electrolytes and ternary cathode materials hinders the widespread application of CSEs, which stems from the decomposition of composite solid-state electrolytes triggered by the high catalytic activity of cobalt and nickel. [23]. Moreover, further researches have shown that the electrochemical performance of solid-state batteries mainly depends on the interface between the solid electrolyte and the cathode, as well as the ion transport inside the cathode [24]. Therefore, to improve the electrochemical performance of solid-state batteries, an ideal CSEs needs to have the ability to stabilize the lithium anode and construct a continuous antioxidant ion channel within the cathode.

Herein, a killing two birds with one stone strategy to construct hierarchical composite solid electrolytes (H-CSEs) was demonstrated. The anode side electrolyte could generate a stable multiphase SEI and regulate the Li+ transport flux. While the cathode side electrolyte could penetrate into the electrode and form a continuous ion conduction pathway. As expected, the H-CSEs exhibited an excellent electrochemical performance in solid-state lithium metal batteries (a specific capacity of 102 mAh g−1 at 1.0C after 300 cycles) and solid-state lithium sulfur batteries (the capacity was 850 mAh g−1 at 0.2C after 60 cycles). Finally, the interface evolution of the battery and ion conduction inside the cathode were studied. This work provides a significance reference for the design of solid-state electrolytes and the optimization of solid-state battery electrochemical performance.

The synthesis process of the CSEs is shown in Fig. 1 . Firstly, the poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene)-BaTiO3 (PHB) framework was prepared by electrospinning. The dielectric ceramics coupled with dielectric polymers were expected to endow electrolytes with piezoelectric properties. Secondly, the Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (LLTO) was synthesized via sol-gel method and heat treatment based on our previous work [25]. Finally, the H-CSEs were prepared by UV induced polymerization of dipropylene glycol diacrylate (TPGDA), 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and LLTO slurry in the PHB skeleton. The DOL-LLTO slurry was cast on the cathode side and following in-situ thermal polymerization. The precursor solution of in-situ thermal polymerization could penetrate into the cathode and generate continuous ion conduction channels.

The structural of the PHB skeleton was analyzed by the scanning electron microscope (SEM). As shown in Fig. S1a-b, the PHB was composed of cross-linked nanofiber, and this intersecting structural could endow the skeleton with high porosity and promote the infiltration of polymer electrolytes and the formation of continuous ion conducting channels. The energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) mapping revealed that elements such as Ba, Ti, O, C, N, and F were distributed on the surface of PHB nanofibers (Fig. S1c). The morphology of the as-synthesized CSEs is shown in Fig. S2. The surface of PHB@PDFL CSE was relatively flat and LLTO fillers had good encapsulation effects (Fig. S2a-b). The electrolyte surface of PHB@DFL CSE exposed many LLTO particles (Fig. S2c-d), which were attributed to the sedimentation of LLTO particles caused by long-term in-situ thermal polymerization. The exposure of LLTO particles could cause side reactions. Fig. S2e-f show the SEM images of PHB@PFL CSE. It was found that the presence of polymer coated LLTO particles on the surface of the electrolyte, confirming that the rapid UV induced free radical polymerization alleviated the settling of fillers in polymers. Notably, there was no obvious settlement effect of LLTO in PHB@PDFL, which attributed to the increased viscosity of electrolyte precursor slurry originated from the cross-linking effect of various polymers, as well as the method of rapid UV induced polymerization. It is noteworthy that the encapsulation of LLTO fillers avoided the direct contact between LLTO and the highly reductive lithium anode, thus avoiding the side reaction between LLTO and the lithium anode, which enhanced the stability of the composite solid electrolyte [12].

The crystal structure information of the material was characterized by XRD. In the LLTO pattern (Fig. 2a), the diffraction peaks of the material were consistent with the single-phase perovskite structure of Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (JCPDS No.87-0935) [26]. In the diffraction pattern of PHB (Fig. 2a), obvious diffraction peaks were closely to the diffraction of tetragonal structure of BaTiO3 (JCPDS No. 05-0626) [27]. In addition, a weak broad peak near 20° was associated with PVDF-HFP polymers. Fig. 2b shows the diffraction patterns of the synthesized CSEs. All the CSEs exhibited some common diffraction peaks consistent with the Li0.33La0.557TiO3. It is worth noting that the diffraction intensity of polymer peak located near 20° in the PHB@PFL electrolyte was higher than that of others, indicating a higher crystallinity of the electrolyte [28]. This result will be further confirmed by DSC. In addition, the corresponding diffraction peaks in the PHB@PDFL and PHB@DFL electrolyte were relatively low, confirming that the crosslinking of PDOL components effectively reduced the crystallinity of PHB@PFL electrolyte. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) were used to investigate the structure and intermolecular interactions of CSEs (Fig. 2c). All electrolytes exhibited a significant bending band of -CH2- at 830 cm−1 [25]. The PHB@PDFL, PHB@PFL and PHB@DFL electrolyte exhibited an additional C-O-C bending vibration at 875 cm−1 belonging to the ether bond [29–31]. Besides, two absorption peaks at 1060 cm−1 and 1840 cm−1 were associated with the asymmetric stretching and symmetric stretching of the CO, respectively [32]. In addition, the signal at 1180 cm−1 was attributed to the bending vibration of the CF bond, which was derived from FEC, LiTFSI and PHB [33]. Moreover, the absorption peak at 1400 cm−1 was belonged to the SO bond, which was attributed to the absorption of LiTFSI [34]. Notably, the bule shift phenomenon was found in the signal of CF, indicating the strong interaction between FEC and electrolyte. Fig. S3a shows the in-situ ring opening polymerization process of DOL initiated by SnF2 initiator. The formed PDOL polymer possessed a larger molecular chain, which effectively reduced the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy of DOL, thus exhibiting a better antioxidant stability [30]. In addition, the chain like polyether structure could facilitate the interaction with Li+ and form fast ion conducting channels [35]. More importantly, the strong Lewis acid Sn2+ was more easily reduced to Sn in the electrolyte than Li+, which effectively inhibited the penetration of lithium dendrites in the electrolyte [36]. The principle of UV induced polymerization is shown in Fig. S3b. Firstly, the initiator of diphenyl (2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl) phosphine oxide (TPO) was cleaved under ultraviolet light to produce radicals. Secondly, the radicals react with the CC bond in TPGDA monomer to form poly (trimethylene glycol diacrylate) (PTPGDA) through a nucleophilic reaction. The polar ether and ester groups in the PTPGDA polymer chain could solvate Li+, reduce the diffusion barrier of lithium ions in the electrolyte, and promote Li+ conduction [37]. In addition, the fillers and additives in CSEs could immobilize anions through Lewis acid-base interactions and hydrogen bonding, thereby improving the ion conductivity of the electrolyte [38,39]. These features improved the electrochemical performance of CSEs.

The glass transition temperature (T
g ) of CSEs was identified by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). As shown in Fig. 2d, the thermal absorption at around 26 °C in the PHB@PDFL and PHB@PFL CSEs was corresponding to the T
g of PTPGDA. While the exothermic peaks around 100 °C and 175 °C were attributed to the melting temperature (T
m ) and cold crystallization temperature (T c) of CSEs, respectively. It was found that the PHB@PDFL CSEs had a lower T
m and higher T
c , which confirmed that the polymer crosslinking could reduce the T
m and increase the T
c of CSEs. In the PHB fiber skeleton test, there was a significant thermal absorption signal near 150 °C, which confirmed that the presence of a small amount of N, N-diethylformamide (DMF) in the PHB. Usually, trace amounts of DMF could participate in the formation of Li+ solvation sheaths, thus promoting the lithium salt dissociation, enhancing the ion transport and the interface stability [40]. In addition, there was no obvious T
g thermal absorption signal in the PHB@DFL and PHB, indicating that the T
g of PDOL and PVDF-HFP component were below than −50 °C. When the application temperature was higher than T
g , the segment movement of CSEs was more intense, enhancing the ion conductivity.

The mechanical properties of CSEs were evaluated by tensile testing. As shown in Fig. 2e, the tensile strength of PHB@PDFL, PHB@DFL, PHB@PFL and PHB were 12.9, 3.0, 1.9 and 0.8 MPa, respectively. Specifically, the PHB@DFL CSE showed a maximum fracture strain of nearly 45 %, which was attributed to the high elasticity of PDOL formed by in-situ polymerization. The higher tensile strength of PHB@PDFL was attributed to the following reasons: firstly, the addition of PBH fiber skeleton with certain mechanical properties enhanced the mechanical properties of the composite solid. Secondly, the cross-linking of polymer molecules formed by UV induced polymerization combined with in-situ polymerization greatly improved the mechanical properties of CSEs. Finally, the dispersion of fillers in polymer matrices was also beneficial for improving mechanical properties.

Previous studies have shown that polarized media with high dielectric constants could enhance the dissociation degree of lithium salts and induce piezoelectric effects during electrochemical processes [13,41,42]. The hysteresis loops were performed to studied the ferroelectric properties of PVDF-HFP and PVDF-HFP@BTO. As shown in Fig. S4, PVDF-HFP exhibited a slender hysteresis line under different electric field intensities, the weak ferroelectricity was attributed to the larger ferroelectric domain size of PVDF-HFP. In contrast, the PVDF-HFP@BTO skeleton exhibited more pronounced ferroelectric relaxation behavior (Fig. 2f). The stronger ferroelectric performance was attributed to the molecular distortion and crystal deformation of PVDF-HFP and BTO. The stronger ferroelectric effect of PHB endowed CSEs with better piezoelectric properties. This suppressed the uneven transport of lithium ions at the interface, reduced the local current density, and promoted the uniform deposition of lithium metal during electrochemical process [9].

The electrochemical stability window of CSEs was test by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). In the first LSV measurement, the electrochemical windows of the PHB@DFL, PHB@PFL and PHB@PDFL CSEs were 3.53, 4.09 and 4.16 V, respectively (Fig. S5). Wherein, the PHB@PDFL possessed the highest initial oxidation potential, indicating that crosslinking with different polymers could enhance the anodic stability of CSEs. In the second LSV test (Fig. 3a), the electrochemical windows of the PHB@DFL, PHB@PFL and PHB@PDFL were increased to 4.71, 4.79 and 5.18 V, respectively. The improved electrochemical window was attributed to the formation of stable SEI. Such an oxidation voltage ensured the electrochemical stability of most cathode materials. In practical applications, cathode active materials are usually more active towards solid electrolytes. LFP was used as a cathode for investigating the electrochemical stability of electrolyte by LSV. As shown in Fig. S6, the electrochemical windows of the PHB@DFL, PHB@PDFL and PHB@PDFL-DFL CSEs were 3.68, 4.71 and 5.69 V, respectively. This result further confirmed that the hierarchical composite solid electrolyte exhibited good stability for cathode materials.

The ion conductivity (σ) of different electrolytes was calculated based on the relationship between temperature and electrochemical impedance. As shown in Fig. S7, Fig. S8 and Fig. S9, the impedance of all solid electrolytes decreased with increasing temperature in 30–80 °C. Based on the relationship between ion conductivity and temperature (Fig. 3b), the activation energy of the electrolyte could be further calculated via Arrhenius equation. The activation energies of PHB@PFL, PHB@DFL and PHB@PDFL were 0.057, 0.045 and 0.048 eV, respectively (Fig. 3c). The ionic conductivity of PHB@DFL, PHB@PDFL and PHB@PFL electrolyte at 30 °C were 7.9 × 10−4, 5.5 × 10−4 and 1.4 × 10−4 S cm−1, respectively (Fig. 3d). The better ion transfer ability of PHB@DFL and PHB@PDFL electrolyte was attributed to the gel properties of PDOL component. It included a small amount of DOL monomer to regulate the solvation of Li+ sheaths, thereby reducing the migration barrier for lithium ions [29]. The Li+ transference number (tLi +) was calculated by constant potential polarization combined with electrochemical impedance measurement. The tLi + of PHB@PDFL, PHB@DFL and PHB@PFL were 0.87, 0.81 and 0.60, respectively (Fig. 3e, Fig. S10 and Fig. S11). The higher tLi + of PHB@PDFL and PHB@DFL was attributed to the better dissociation effect of PDOL on lithium salts. In addition, owing to the dependence of ion transfer in polymers on chain segment motion, the PHB@DFL electrolytes with higher degrees of amorphous state exhibited more intense ion migration [43]. Therefore, the tLi + of PHB@DFL was lower than PHB@PDFL electrolyte. The inhibitory ability of CSEs on lithium dendrite penetration was explored by critical current density (CCD). As shown in Fig. 3f, the critical current density of Li/PHB@PDFL/Li batteries exceeded 2.0 mA cm−2. As a comparison, the Li/PHB@DFL/Li and Li/PHB@PFL/Li batteries exhibited fluctuations at lower current densities (Fig. S12 and Fig. S13). The lower critical current densities indicated lower resistance on lithium dendrite penetration. The high critical current density of Li/PHB@PDFL/Li batteries was attributed to the formation of a stable SEI, which improved the compatibility between the electrolyte and the lithium anode. In addition, the Tafel plots revealed that the exchange current density of Li/PHB@PDFL/Li cell was higher than that of Li/PHB@PFL/Li, demonstrating the formation of a more kinetically favorable charge-transfer interface between Li and the PHB@PDFL electrolyte (Fig. 3g) [44,45]. Notably, the Li/PHB@DFL/Li exhibited the highest exchange current density, which was attributed to the enhancement effect of the DFL gel property on interfacial ion transport. Subsequently, the stability of the CSEs and lithium anode was investigated via lithium plating/stripping experiments. As shown in Fig. 3h, the Li/PHB@PDFL/Li battery maintained a stability polarization voltage of 205 mV after 700 h. While the polarization voltages of Li/PHB@PFL/Li and Li/PHB@DFL/Li batteries after 700 h were 430 and 290 mV, respectively. Significantly, the as-synthesized CSEs exhibited significant polarization in the early cycles, which was attributed to the formation of SEI. Additionally, the PHB@DFL exhibited significant voltage fluctuations during the cycling process, indicating poor stability towards lithium metals. The PHB@PFL exhibited good stability towards lithium metals, but significant polarization phenomena occurred due to slow ion transport kinetics.

Based on the comprehensive consideration of the ion conductivity, interface stability, electrolyte morphology and polymerization methods of the three aforementioned CSEs. The H-CSEs were constructed to solve the anode problem of solid-state lithium-metal batteries and to improve ion transport of cathode. To investigate the stability of H-CSEs in Li/CSEs/LFP batteries, the antioxidant stability of batteries was tested by electrochemical flotation experiments. As shown in Fig. 3i, the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP batteries showed a better electrochemical stability, indicating the good compatibility between the H-CSEs and the cathode. In addition, the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP batteries also exhibited smaller leakage currents, indicating better ion transport kinetics.

Fig. 4a shows the cycling performance of the Li/CSEs/LFP battery at 60 °C and 0.2C for 100 cycles, the discharge capacities of Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP, Li/PHB@PDFL/LFP and Li/PHB@DFL/LFP battery were 131, 71 and 49 mAh g−1, respectively. The corresponding initial Coulomb efficiency (ICE) of three battery was 91 %, 85 % and 77 %, respectively (Fig. 4b, Fig. S14 and Fig. S15). The Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP batteries exhibited high initial capacity and capacity retention, which was attributed to the in-situ construction of the DFL electrolyte layer on the cathode side, thus enhancing the interface contact of the solid electrolyte with the cathode and the ion conduction inside the positive electrode. In addition, the PHB@PDFL layer provided high ion conductivity and constructed a stable SEI, which not only stabilized the lithium anode but also enhanced the ion conduction at the interface. Meanwhile, the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP batteries also showed the best rate performance (Fig. 4c). The long cycling performance was investigated at 1.0C, as shown in Fig. 4d, The Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP cell possessed an initial discharge capacity of is 110 mAh g−1 and a capacity of 102 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles. This was far superior to the electrochemical performance of Li/PHB@PDFL/LFP and Li/PHB@DFL/LFP batteries. Compared with other reported organic and inorganic complex electrolytes, the PHB@PDFL-DFL and PHB@DFL solid electrolytes of this work clearly exhibited the best electrochemical performance by far (Table S1).

The reaction kinetics of different Li/CSEs/LFP batteries were further studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV). As shown in Fig. 4e, all the batteries exhibited consistent electrochemical behavior. The oxidation peak and reduction peak of the battery were located near 3.5 V and 3.0 V, respectively, which corresponded to the reversible reaction between Fe2+/Fe3+ redox pairs. Notably, the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP battery highlighted in this system, with a redox potential difference (ΔE) of only 0.48 V, significantly lower than that of Li/PHB@PDFL/LFP battery. These results confirmed that the construction of DFL positive electrode side electrolyte promoted the diffusion of lithium ions at the positive electrode interface and inside the positive electrode, thereby improving the reaction kinetics of Li/PHB@PDFL/LFP batteries.

To improve the energy density of solid-state batteries, the CSEs needed to be matched with high specific capacity cathode. The pre-prepared S/Co0.85Se-CNT@CP (S cathode) was used as a solid-state cathode [46], and studied the electrochemical performance of solid-state lithium sulfur batteries. In the CV curve of the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S, Li/PHB@PDFL/S and Li/PHB@DFL/S battery (Fig. 4f), the two reduction peaks located in the range of 2.2–2.0 V and 1.9–1.7 V were correspond to the reduction of S8 to long-chain polysulfides (Li2Sx, 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) and the subsequent reduction to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S, respectively. The oxidation peak located in the 2.5–3.0 V range corresponded to the oxidation of Li2S/Li2S2 to sulfur. In addition, the large ΔE between the reduction peak and oxidation peak of the Li/PHB@PDFL/S battery indicated severe polarization of the battery. Fig. 4g shows the results of solid-state lithium sulfur batteries at 0.2C and 60 °C for 60 cycles. The Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S cell displayed durable cycling performance with a specific capacity of 850 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles, which was higher than that of Li/PHB@PDFL/S (350 mAh/g) and Li/PHB@DFL/S (323 mAh/g). In addition, the charge discharge curve of Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S battery revealed an ICE of 96 % (Fig. S16). The cycling performance of Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S battery at 1.0C is shown in Fig. 4h, and the battery still had a discharge capacity of 320 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles.

Usually, the fluidity of DOL monomers enables them to penetrated to the gaps of cathode, and the in-situ polymerization of monomers improved the interface contact between the cathode and the electrolyte. To explore the interface evolution of the cathode, the structure of cathode before and after cycling was revealed by SEM. Fig. S17a-b show the detailed structural of the LFP coated on aluminum foil. The particle distribution on the surface of the fresh cathode was chaotic accompanied with many gaps, which limited the contact between the cathode and electrolyte, resulting in slow ion transport kinetics. Fig. S17c-d show the composite cathode surface formed by in-situ polymerization of LFP cathode and cathode side electrolyte. The gaps on the LFP cathode were filled with DFL electrolyte, which greatly increased the utilization of the active material and improved the interface contact between cathode and electrolyte. Similarly, the S cathode was also filled by the electrolyte (Fig. S17e-f), which not only improved the ion conduction inside the cathode, but also promoted the conversion kinetics of polysulfides. Furthermore, the chemical composition of CEI was identified by XPS. The C 1s spectrum (Fig. S18 and Table S1) displayed three peaks located at 284.8 eV, 286.4 eV, and 288.9 eV, which belonged to the CC, C-O-R, and CO bond, respectively [47,48]. Specifically, the C-O-R bond was originated from the PDOL electrolyte and the PEO binder, while the CO bond was derived from the polar oxygen-containing groups at the end of the polymer. Notably, in the F 1s spectrum (Fig. 5a), it was found that the peaks at 684.8 eV and 688.4 eV were ascribed to inorganic LiF and organic fluorine containing groups [49,50], respectively, which confirmed that the formation of CEI containing LiF. The generation of LiF originated from the decomposition of LiTFSI and FEC during the electrochemical process. Usually, the CEI rich in LiF exhibited weak interactions with LFP cathode, which could alleviate the volume strain of the active material and inhibit the decomposition of the solid electrolyte [51,52]. The Sn 3d spectrum is shown in Fig. 5b. The binding energies at 487.5 and 495.7 eV were corresponded to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Sn2+, while the binding energies located at 486.5 and 495.0 eV could be attributed to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbitals of Sn [53,54]. The signal of Sn2+ was originated from SnF2 in the DFL ion conducting network. While the signal of Sn was derived from the strong Lewis acid Sn2+ in DFL electrolyte, which was easier to capture electrons and reduce to Sn [36]. The P 2p peaks were located at 133.4 eV and 134.3 eV, corresponding to the phosphate group (PO4 3−) [55], which was consistent with the LFP active material (Fig. 5c). The XPS results confirmed that the cathode interface in Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP solid-state batteries formed a CEI rich in organic species and inorganic LiF/Sn, which alleviated the interface instability and structural degradation of LFP. In addition, the similar results were found in Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S solid-state lithium sulfur batteries (Fig. S19).

To elucidate the effect of electrolytes on lithium anode, the structure and chemical composition of lithium anodes after cycling was studied. Fig. S20a-b show the SEM image of lithium anode in Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/TLFP battery after 300 cycles. The lithium anode presented a tight accumulation and formed a relatively flat contact surface. The tight stacking was attributed to the formation of a dense SEI, while the lateral growth was owing to the regulatory effect of the piezoelectric effect of PHB framework on lithium dendrite deposition. Accordingly, the morphology of the lithium anode in the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S battery after 200 cycles exhibited a flat morphology, but there were significant cracks and pores (Fig. S20c-d). These pores exposed highly active lithium anodes during the electrochemical process, causing interface side reactions and reducing the cycling performance of solid-state lithium sulfur batteries.

XPS was used to investigate the chemical composition of the Li anode. Firstly, the Li anode in Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP battery at 1.0C after cycling was studied. The F 1s spectrum (Fig. 5d) displays two peaks at approximately 684.8 eV and 688.7 eV, which were assigned to the LiF and organic fluorinated groups, respectively [47]. The signals of Sn 3d (Fig. 5e) were divided into two peaks at 486.3 and 494.8 eV attributed to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of LixSn, respectively. These peaks originated from the reduction of SnF2 initiator by the lithium anode [53,56]. Due to the unreduced Sn2+ in the electrolyte, the other pair of peaks at 487.5 and 495.8 eV belonged to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Sn2+. Besides, the P 2p orbital could be fitted as two binding energies located at 133.4 and 134.3 eV, corresponding to the binding energy of the PO4 3− (Fig. 5f) [55]. These results confirmed that the SEI of Li anode in Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP battery after cycling was mainly composed of organic species and inorganic LiF/Li3PO4/LixSn. These SEI components had high interface energy and high ionic conductivity, which could enhance the nucleation energy of lithium dendrites and reduces the overpotential of lithium plating/stripping. In addition, the C 1s spectrum could be fitted as three peaks located at 284.8 eV, 285.7 eV, and 289.8 eV, belonging to the CC, C-O-R, and organic CO bonds, respectively (Fig. S21 and Table S2). Wherein, the C-O-R was mainly originated from the SEI formed by the reaction between the lithium anode and the polymer. While the CO bond was stemmed from the formation of carbonate species, a direct result of the reaction between Li and air. The low signal intensity of CO3 2− indicated good air resistance stability. Similarly, the same SEI composition was also found in the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S sample (Fig. S22), which confirmed that H-CSEs have the same effect on anodes.

To investigated the regulatory effect of polarized media on Li+ transport flux and lithium metal deposition, the asymmetric Li/PHB@PDFL/Cu battery in the voltage range of 2.0–4.2 V and at a current density of 200 mAg−1 after 100 cycles was disassembled. As shown in Fig. 6a-b and Fig. S23, the PHB@PDFL CSEs-mediated lithium metal deposition on the Cu electrode presented a dense appearance with even granular protrusions distributed on the surface. There were obvious inhibitory marks on the protruding parts of the Cu electrode surface, indicating that solid electrolytes had an inhibitory effect on lithium deposition at protrusions. Subsequently, the electric field and Li+ diffusion behavior around the protrusion of the lithium anode interface were analyzed by finite element simulation. In the electric field distribution with the piezoelectric electrolyte (Fig. 6c), the counter voltage around the protrusion was significantly reduced, indicating that the piezoelectric electrolyte could reduce the local electric field. However, the counter potential around the protrusion tends was more enriched in the non-piezoelectric electrolytes, indicating the enhancement of local electric field at the protuberance (Fig. 6d). In the distribution of lithium ions, the piezoelectric electrolyte reduced the Li+ concentration in the raised area relative to the planar region. This indicated that the piezoelectric electrolyte could disperse the Li+ flux around the raised area by redu7cing the local electric field strength, allowing Li+ to preferentially deposit in the planar region, thereby alleviating the growth of lithium dendrites. In the ion distribution of non-piezoelectric electrolytes, the enhanced electric field generated by the ‘tip effect’ enriched the ion flux around the protrusion, which promoted the growth of lithium dendrites. Fig. 6e shows the variation of Li+ average concentration in the direction of horizontal position. The two electrolytes had opposite trends of change along the horizontal direction. Concretely, the piezoelectric electrolyte had a higher ion distribution concentration far from the protrusion, indicating that the piezoelectric electrolyte could dynamically regulate the Li+ flux, thereby forming a uniform deposition layer.

Based on the above discussion, the PHB@PDFL anode side electrolyte could construct a multiphase SEI and internal electric field during the electrochemical process, which improved the compatibility of the anode and homogenizing the Li+ flux (Fig. 7a). The DFL cathode side electrolyte could fill the gaps on the electrode surface with electrolytes and construct a fast cathode ion conducting channel, thus improving the utilization rate of active materials. Besides, the DFL electrolyte promoted the formation of a CEI rich in LiF and Sn to stabilization of the cathode (Fig. 7b). These results collectively improved the electrochemical performance of solid-state batteries.

In summary, we developed H-CSEs with highly compatible with lithium anodes and capable of constructing cathode ion conductive networks. The ferroelectric analysis confirmed that the PHB framework constructed by coupling dielectric ceramics with dielectric polymers endowed solid electrolytes with stronger piezoelectric responsiveness. While the finite element simulation confirmed that the piezoelectric electrolyte reduced the local electric field strength, allowing lithium ions to preferentially deposit in the planar region. In addition, XPS confirmed that the formation of electrode electrolyte interface improved the stability of solid-state batteries. The electrochemical test results confirmed that the H-CSEs promoted the electrochemical performance of SLMBs. The Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/LFP battery performed a capacity of 131 mAh g−1 at 0.2C after 100 cycles and the Li/PHB@PDFL-DFL/S battery delivered a capacity of 850 mAh g−1 after 60 cycles at 0.2C. This work brought new opportunities for the commercialization process of high-energy solid-state Li metal batteries.
